narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about a variety of topics in algorithmic approaches to computer music, including sound basics, digital audio representations, rule-based composition, uncertainty, autonoma, and procedural systems. I also learned about interesting applications in video games, live coding, and predicting the future.
Cool computer music knowledge
Music knowledge and how to make music on my own.
good
music making with supercollider.
Music knowledge as well as supercollider skills
Using computer to generate music
I learned a lot about SuperCollider, computer music, and music theory in general. I had no background knowledge in music and am very excited about how much I learned about music in general.
Music theory and coding

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The openness of the course projects allows students to explore a variety of applications to the topics discussed in lecture. The course could benefit greatly from a more in-depth introduction to SuperCollider, specifically with regard to syntax, functions, and object definitions. To some extent, a student's experience with the class projects could be greatly improved with more instruction on the actual language of the course as opposed to relying on online documentation. Since experience in SuperCollider and sound synthesis are very useful for algorithmic and heuristic composition, I would recommend that CPSC 432 be taught in the Fall with CPSC 431 following in the Spring.
Great course
The team discussion part in class could be improved.
good
Very high engagement
Great class. SuperCollider is a finnicky programming language but nobody has any experience with it going in and the professor did a lot of programming teaching to help throughout the class.
All good

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I definitely would recommend this course to any students who are comfortable with object-oriented programming and have an interest in computer-generated music. Computer science students should take into account that the class projects are not like other CS assignments. There is no spec with required functionality, but instead, there are guidelines for what each project should focus on. This openness is definitely something to take into account, as the workload of the course pretty much depends on how much effort one wants to dedicate to each project and how much one wants to get out of it. Since having a background in sound synthesis can be helpful when creating algorithmic music and experience in SuperCollider helps immensely as well, I HIGHLY recommend taking CPSC 432 BEFORE CPSC 431.
Great course

Yes! This course is great for learning about the intersection of music and computer science. Note that if you are looking to work with a DAW, this course does not really touch the subject unless you choose to integrate Supercollider with a DAW for the final project. Still though, speaking as a (past) musician majoring in computer science, this course was an ideal blend of the two subjects.
Yes, I would recommend to any students in engineering major who are interested in music.
good
I would if some one is interested in computer music
If you are interested in music or just looking for a cool, kind of different elective I would recommend it.
Yes
